quotes.quote: I don't have any tricky plays, I'd rather have tricky players.
No coach has ever won a game by what he knows; it's what his players know that counts.
Every great player has learned the two Cs: how to concentrate and how to maintain composure.
Mentally, the only players who survive in the pros are the ones able to manage all their responsibilities.
I think it's the mark of a great player to be confident in tough situations.
Some players you pat their butts, some players you kick their butts, some players you leave alone.
Although I wanted my players to work to win, I tried to convince them they had always won when they had done their best.
Talent is secondary to whether players are confident.
Great players are willing to give up their own personal achievement for the achievement of the group. It enhances everybody.
Players have two things to do. Play and keep their mouths shut.
The best players will play. That's the way it will always be.
He who gets the best players usually wins.
People have to understand how important it is for the players to let off steam, switch off and relax.
Sometimes a player's greatest challenge is coming to grips with his role on the team.
I like my players to be married and in debt. That's the way you motivate them.
So if the players trust the coach, it's not a problem. If the players don't trust the coach, it is a problem, and vice versa.
Players are artists who create their own reality within the game.
Players respond to coaches who really have their best interests at heart.
Players must do what you want them to do in pressure situations.
The difference of great players is at a certain point in a match they raise their level of play and maintain it. Lesser players play great for a set, but then less.
Finding good players is easy. Getting them to play as a team is another story.
Players play, tough players win.
Everyone knows the game is about the players.
It's not the name that makes the player. It's the player.
Most players prepare for disaster. A good player prepares for success.
The one thing about players today is that they're very sensitive, and very fragile. They didn't grow up with tough coaches.
I think every player should think that he's a difference maker.
I don't believe a player is ever a finished product.
